sub_topic: Determining the edge connectivity of a graph.
message_1: Consider a graph with five vertices A, B, C, D, and E, and the following edges (AB, AC, BD, CD, CE, and DE). Determine the minimum number of edges that need to be removed to disconnect the graph.
message_2:
To disconnect the graph, we need to ensure that there is no path between any pair of vertices. We can achieve this by removing edges in such a way that at least one vertex becomes isolated (i.e., it has no edges connecting it to any other vertex).

In this graph, we can disconnect it by removing the following edges: AB, AC, and CE. After removing these edges, vertex A and vertex E will be isolated, and the graph will be disconnected.

So, the minimum number of edges that need to be removed to disconnect the graph is 3.
